description.narrative:
The IDH Farmfit Fund invests in agri-commodity traders, agri SMEs, and/or financial institutions with attributable benefit to smallholder farmers in developing countries (DAC List of ODA Recipients). It focuses on food, staple and cash crops including, cocoa, coffee, cotton, palm oil, tea, aquaculture, soy, cassava, rice and other commodities.
In this context, the Fund defines smallholder farmers as marginal and sub-marginal farm households constrained in size and resources. Some sources define smallholder farmers as those who cultivate between 1 hectare to 10 hectares (for more semi-arid areas) of land. While they will vary in farm size and crop/livestock distribution according to their activity and region, common characteristics of smallholder farmers are that they have low access to technology, limited resources in terms of capital, skills, and risk management, depend on family labour for most activities, and have limited capacity in terms of storage, marketing, and processing.

The IDH Farmfit Fund is a EUR 100 million de-risking blended finance fund, representing a joint investment from the Dutch Government and five international brands. The IDH Farmfit Fund takes the highest risk positions in farmer related transactions, thereby reducing the farmer risk currently born by borrowers and lenders. By doing so it catalyses commercial capital to co-invest in this sector and allow agri-commodity traders, agri SMEs, and/or financial institutions to expand the services that they provide to smallholder farmers. Note that the Fund is a revolving facility, so after 2026, the budgeted amounts are expected to exceed incoming committments.

The objective of the Fund is to demonstrate that farmer financing is possible in a sustainable way by building a large and sound farmer centric investment portfolio with both value chain actors and financial institutions. This will increase the availability of affordable, long term financing to farmers leading to significant improvements in smallholder farmer lives and incomes.
